posts.name: sigfun
posts.cooked:
I have 2 contacts that appear as if they don’t have Signal. I thought they had got bored with the app and had uninstalled it. I called them with a normal call and asked what happened. Turns out both have kept their same devices and haven’t uninstalled/reinstalled the app, and their phone number is the same. Signal was asking them about verification “Are you human?” type of verification plus theybhad to introduce a verification code sent to their device via SMS. Why did this happen?

Once they verified again their account they could message me again, because before they couldn’t.
What’s bad is that Signal created a new chat and the old one, with all the chat history is there, but says that the person doesn’t use Signal.

Whatever is happening that causes this, either a bug or intentional, it is appalling, incredible bad, horrible, UX. People thought I was ignoring them and I thought they had decided to uninstall the app.
Mind you, these people aren’t young and I we don’t talk frequently.

This should be reviewed, seriously. One of the worst experiences I’ve had in an app. Literally thought people were angry/annoyed at me and vice-versa. I am now wondering if all those contacts that I have as “This person no longer uses Signal” is unintentional.
Debug logs from their apps would probably help.

posts.name: sigfun
posts.cooked:
Nah, Signal is seriously lacking better debugging strategies. The standard deflection mechanism of asking for logs is ridiculous. There’s not enough testing done. I work on software, I know how this works, can’t bamboozle me on this one.

I can’t ask senior people (70+) for that kind info, specially if they appeared as not using Signal for over 2 months, don’t be absurd; the info won’t either be there. They could barely understand they had to do something again and thought the application was working as usual but couldn’t understand why messages wouldn’t send.
This is a general iOS problem, Signal messed something up since last year and a bit more.

What the Signal team needs to do is hire more people to do more testing and address bugs fast. They are working with a handful of engineers.

The UX in Signal is abysmal. This is literally the worst experience I’ve ever had with any app, and worse as I donate regularly. Pretty pissed off and re thinking why have I wasted so many years (I’ve been using it sonce it was called TextSecure) for an app that clearly lacks resources for the enormous amount of work that is on the horizon.

sigfun:

There’s not enough testing done. I work on software, I know how this works, can’t bamboozle me on this one.

That’s hard to say up front without knowing what the problem was.

posts.name: sigfun
posts.cooked:
Of course, but I don’t see WhatsApp asking their user base for logs.
It is simply coincidence that I am technically literate and I am in this forum. Do you think that 99% of the Signal user base are aware of that? Of course not.
The process is broken. Figuring what the problem is, is the engineer’s responsibility, not the users. As far as I know my contacts aren’t participating in any kind of beta but they have been struck with a nasty bug.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
Signal has a help form IN APP, you’re asking volunteers on a forum for help how are we going to help you without logs? If it’s too much feel free to contact support via the in app help form :)

I understand you’re upset, but this really is the only way to get help.

posts.name: sigfun
posts.cooked:
I get it but take into account the following:

  1. The point of posting in the forum is to get direct help from the devs. The volunteers are fine, I am one because I care about reporting issues and suggesting improvements, but this kind of problems goes beyond us
  2. I don’t have access to the affected devices
  3. The owners of the devices are over 70 years old and not technically literate
  4. They are busy and don’t have time to submit anything, an app should be a seamless experience. They are not part of any beta testing program, and they shouldn’t care about fixing problems.
  5. They only use the app because I do, they couldn’t care less if the app doesn’t work, as it is not critical for their use, but is critical to me because I believe in rigurous privacy and is the only chat app I use, so it is me who has to report with what I have at hand.

This is a problem is for developers. Asking for logs is a crutch for process deficiencies. That’s what one does as a developer, not something one asks to end users.

Something broke really badly and users can’t be responsible to fix it.

sigfun:

The point of posting in the forum is to get direct help from the devs.

This is the Signal Community forum and the point is for unofficial community support. The devs don’t commonly interact here outside of the beta topics. If you need official support you need to contact them via the official support website. If you want to report a bug to the devs, the place for that is GitHub.

sigfun:

Asking for logs is a crutch for process deficiencies. That’s what one does as a developer, not something one asks to end users.

Asking for logs is a necessity because it is literally nearly impossible to determine the cause of a problem without some kind of event details. Signal requires this because they don’t have any kind of usage information or automatic bug reports that go to them, so the only way to get any information is to have someone submit logs for the developers to look at. Sure it’s not always convenient and may not be feasible for everyone, but that’s how it has to be if you want privacy. Even big name corporations with paid software will ask users for logs sometimes in certain situations.

sigfun:

The point of posting in the forum is to get direct help from the devs.

No, the point of the forum is to engage with the community. The developers also use the forum for beta testing and will occasionally engage in the other topics.

I was the poster who first mentioned logs in this thread, and I didn’t ask for them but only pointed out that they would help. Part of that statement was also to point out that it would need to be logs from their devices and that logs from yours would likely not be helpful.

sigfun:

I don’t see WhatsApp asking their user base for logs.

Search for Whatsapp crash iOS and find this:
https://discussions.apple.com/thread/254748266?sortBy=rank

Every platform will have issues.

link_counts.title: WhatsApp keeps crashing on iPhone 13 Pro … - Apple Community

posts.cooked:
sigfun:

They are busy and don’t have time to submit anything, an app should be a seamless experience. They are not part of any beta testing program, and they shouldn’t care about fixing problems.

Do they drive a car? Do they have heating in their homes? Are they expecting that those things will magically get fixed without telling somebody that they broke?

posts.name: sigfun
posts.cooked:
I thought the forum was also frequently used ny the devs to have a more direct approach to solving issues. If that’s not the case, then my mistake.

TeeJay82:

Do they drive a car? Do they have heating in their homes? Are they expecting that those things will magically get fixed without telling somebody that they broke?

That’s a flawed comparison. There’s a huge difference between:

  1. Things that are critical to your life, like a car, certain appliances, even banking apps, and a niche app like Signal which they don’t care at all and only use because I do. Since I am the one that cares, I am reporting it. They didn’t complain about it not working, simply assumed it was so and went on with their lifes. Signal might be critical for whistleblowers but not the vast majority of chat app users
  2. New technology and old technology, like a car

Your comment is tone deaf. Do you think people over 70 yo would know how to interact with support for an app that very few people use? I don’t you have sufficient exposure to the real world to know how tech illiterate some people are around the world…

sigfun:

Things that are critical to your life, like a car, certain appliances, even banking apps, and a niche app like Signal which they don’t care at all and only use because I do.

So Signal should aim for becoming 100% bug free to appease people who don’t care about it? That sounds unreasonable. And extremely costly.

sigfun:

Do you think people over 70 yo would know how to interact with support for an app that very few people use? I don’t you have sufficient exposure to the real world to know how tech illiterate some people are around the world…

No. But that doesn’t change that it’s unreasonable to expect Signal to fix problems without anybody telling them about those problems to begin with.

On Android the support button is two taps away, btw.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
sigfun:

I thought the forum was also frequently used ny the devs to have a more direct approach to solving issues. If that’s not the case, then my mistake.

No worries! Usually Signal support will take care of those sort of issues :)
You can contact Signal support in app in Settings > Help > Contact Us

posts.name: sigfun
posts.cooked:
I think you are missing the point. The point is not bug free, I know how it is, I get it. But what shouldn’t happen is major bugs like this going out to the public.
I don’t have an answer on how this should be tackled on but more internal testing and more hiring should do.
Again, the only reason this “report” exists is because I know about the forums, I am motivated enough to report it, and I am tech literate. In other circumstances the problem would be there, people would have uninstalled the app and that’s it. Pretty sad end to such an important app given the amount of effort that has been put into it, and again, its importance (probably future importance even more) in society.
This bugs are deal breakers, not minor bugs.

sigfun:

I think you are missing the point. The point is jot bug free, I know how it is, I get it. But what shouldn’t happen is major bugs like this going out to the public.

Without knowing what triggered the captcha it’s impossible to tell if it even was a bug.

That they now show up as separate contacts is inelegant, though.

The fact that they showed up as separate chats on your end make it clear that their original accounts were unregistered.

Are there any timers or reasons that an unused account would get deregistered?

posts.name: sigfun
posts.cooked:
CueHD:

Are there any timers or reasons that an unused account would get deregistered?

That’s my exact thought. There must be something unregister them. But whatever it is less than a year, and no warning telling them about the issue.

sigfun:

and no warning telling them about the issue

I’m not surprised by the lack of warning.

Did those two contacts have “This person no longer uses Signal” in your conversations prior to you calling them?

posts.name: sigfun
posts.cooked:
CueHD:

Did those two contacts have “This person no longer uses Signal” in your conversations prior to you calling them?

Yes. As I mentioned, from my side, they appeared as “This person no longer uses Signal” but from their side, they could still write me but the messages wouldn’t go out.
Could you please give a timeline of what happened on their end then? Because “they could still write me” appears to contradict that they were asked for verification.
